stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: C2 Site Identified in Malware Incident Against a DIB Organization
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On 4 September 2014, the command and control (C2) site lanxess-lab.com (106.187.45.162) was identified in a malware incident against a defense industrial base (DIB) organization.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
(U//FOUO) The attackers leveraged the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) version of TokenControl malware to compromise a DIB system. The TokenControl malware sent network traffic three times to the attacker-controlled C2 infrastructure at IP 106.187.45.162, which was associated with the domain lanxess-lab.com.
(U//FOUO) The following network traffic was observed:
Destination IP: 106.187.45.162 Destination Port: 443 Time: 4 September 1806Z
Destination IP: 106.187.45.162 Destination Port: 443 Time: 4 September 1807Z
Destination IP: 106.187.45.162 Destination Port: 443 Time: 4 September 1810Z
(U//FOUO) The following SNORT signature can be used to detect this traffic:
alert tcp any 443 -> any any (msg:"TokenControl SSL Implant"; content:"|00 a8 b7 14 44 09 c0 80 fb 0a c5 0b b8 03 ed|"; sid:1; rev:1;)
(U) According to third party reports, the domain name lanxess-lab.com (103.24.0.142) spoofs a materials and chemicals company based in Germany. The campaign involved a watering hole attack against the chemical sector on 26 August 2014. This domain was used as a C2 site.
